EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



PAPCO, Inc. (PAPCO) owns and operates a natural gas liquids recovery facility, the Warren Fractionation Plant, in Clarendon Pennsylvania.  The plant is designed to recover liquid products from natural gas via physical separation, dehydration, and refrigeration.  Petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas.  The plant handles and stores process flammables such as methane, ethane, propane, butane, isobutane, pentane, isopentane, and heavier components.  Some of the flammables are in excess of the threshold quantities.  PAPCO management is aware of potential hazards posed by processing and storing natural gas and natural gas liquids.  Programs are established to prevent accidental releases and train personnel for emergency response in the event of a release.  The Warren Plant has no recordable accidents in the past five years.   



PAPCO has considered the impact of a "worst case" accident.  A radius of impact has been calculated using the EPA's RMP*Comp software.  Global Positioning System (GPS) was utilized to estimate public receptors within the impacted area.  It has been determined that the worst case event would affect nearby structures an

d consideration of the impacted area has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.



PAPCO implements safety programs and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic releases.  Operation, maintenance, training, and inspection procedures are being implemented.  In addition, PAPCO has coordinated with local emergency responders, including the Warren Fire and Rescue Department, Clarendon Fire Department, Warren County Sheriff Department, Warren Police Department and the Warren Emergency Management.  Warren Plant personnel and responders have been given an Emergency Response Plan. 



With these objectives in mind, this Risk Management Plan is developed to provide information about our management of risks associated with natural gas processing and liquids recovery.  We stress our commitment to ensuring a safe operation for our employees, our visitors, and our community.







2.0 TITLE 40 PART 68, SUBPART B - HAZARD ASSESSMENT



The required elements of hazard assessment from '40 cfr Part 68' are as follows:

     68.20 Applicability.

     68.33 Defining offsite impacts - environment.

     68.36 Review and update.

     68.39 Documentation.

     68.42 Five-year accident history.







2.1 Input Parameters - 68.20 / 68.22



The PAPCO fractionation plant consists of piping systems and storage facilities.  A worst case scenario release of propane has been analyzed using an estimated maximum quantity of the process flammable.  Methane, ethane, propane, butane, iso-butane, pentane, and iso-pentane quantities were provided in weight percentage and then converted to pounds (lbs).







2.2 Worst-case release scenario analysis - 68.25



In this worst-case release scenario analysis, the total quantity of a tank is assumed to

be involved in a vapor cloud explosion (VCE).  An analysis of this explosion was done using EPA's RMP*Comp software.  The input parameters are as follows:  



     EPA RMP*Comp

     Chemical:  Propane

     Category:  Flammable

     Scenario:  Worst-case

     Release Type:  Vapor Cloud Explosion (VCE)

     Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:

     Wind Speed (assumption):  1.5 m/s (3.4 mph)

     Stability Class (assumption):  F

     Air Temperature (assumption):  77 degrees F (25 degrees C)   







2.3 Alternative release scenario analysis - 68.28



Gaseous Release from Process Piping:



Instead of assuming release of the entire contents of a vessel containing a flammable gas, PAPCO decided to consider a more likely scenario such as release from a hole in a vessel or pipe.  To estimate the gas leak, a simplified equation was used to estimate a release rate based on the size of the hole, pipe pressure, and properties of the gas.  This equation applies to choked flow or maximum gas flow rate.  Choked flow generally would be expected for gases under pressure.



To summarize, a pipe containing a flammable gas is broken.  The release rate was estimated from the simplified equation.  In the alternative release scenario analysis, it was assumed that the vapor cloud was released and ignited, resulting in a Vapor Cloud Fire (VCF). 2.7 Review and Update - 68.36



PAPCO will review and update the offsite consequence analyses at least once every five years.  If changes in processes, quantities stored or handled, or any other aspect of the stationary source might reasonably be expected to increase or decrease the worst-case distance to the endpoint by a factor of two or more, PAPCO will complete a revised analysis within six months of the change and submit a revised Risk Management Plan.







2.8 Five Year Accident History - 68.42



PAPCO has not recorded any accidents that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known of any off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage within the last five years.







3.0 TITLE 40 PART 68, SUBPART D - PROGRAM 3 PREVENTION PROGRAM

 

The required elements of the prevention program from '40 cfr Part 68' are as follows:

     68.65 Process safety information.

     68.67 Process hazard analysis.

     68.69 Operating procedures.

     68.71 Training.

     68.75 Management of change.

     68.81 Incident investigation.

     68.83 Employee participation.

     68.85 Hot work permit.

3.1 Introduction



The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the Warren Fractionation Plant.  Processes are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  This summary addresses each of the OSHA's PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention pr

11) Safety systems and their functions.



Operating procedures will be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain a process.  The operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and stationary sources.  PAPCO will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate.  PAPCO has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into a stationary source by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel.  These safe work practices apply to PAPCO employees and contractor employees.







3.5 Training - 68.71



Each employee presently involved in operating a process and each employee before being involved in operating a newly assigned process is trained in an overview of the process and operating procedures as specified in 68.69.  The training includes emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks.  Refresher training will be provided every three years and more often, if necessary, to each employee involved in operating a process to assure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures of the process.  PAPCO, in consultation with the employees involved in operating the process, shall determine the appropriate frequency of refresher training.  PAPCO will ascertain documentation that each employee involved in operating a process has received and understood the required training.
